Pro and Max:''' {{Start date and age|2024|11|8}} }}}} '''Apple M4''' is a series of [[ARM architecture family|ARM]]-based [[system on a chip]] (SoC) designed by [[Apple Inc.]], part of the [[Apple silicon]] series, including a [[central processing unit]] (CPU), a [[graphics processing unit]] (GPU), a [[neural processing unit]] (NPU), and a [[digital signal processor]] (DSP). The M4 chip was introduced in May 2024 for the [[iPad Pro (7th generation)]], and is the fourth generation of the [[Apple silicon#M series|M series Apple silicon architecture]], succeeding the [[Apple M3]].{{Cite web |last=Leswing |first=Kif |date=May 7, 2024 |title=Apple announces new iPad Pro with M4, new iPad Air tablets |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2024/05/07/apple-ipad-pro-and-ipad-air-2024-announced.html |access-date=May 8, 2024 |website=CNBC |publisher=NBCUniversal |language=en-US}}{{Cite web |last=Warren |first=Tom |date=May 7, 2024 |title=Next-gen M4 chips start arriving in Apple devices this year |url=https://www.theverge.com/2024/5/7/24148451/apple-m4-chip-ai-ipad-macbook |access-date=May 8, 2024 |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |language=en-US}}{{Cite press release |title=Apple introduces M4 chip |url=https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2024/05/apple-introduces-m4-chip/ |publisher=Apple Inc. |language=en-US |location=Cupertino, CA |date=May 7, 2024 |access-date=May 8, 2024}} It was followed by the professional-focused '''M4 Pro''' and '''M4 Max''' in October 2024'''.'''{{Cite web |last=Benedetto |first=Antonio G. Di |date=2024-10-30 |title=Apple updates the MacBook Pro with M4 Pro and M4 Max chips |url=https://www.theverge.com/2024/10/30/24270706/apple-macbook-pro-m4-pro-max-14-16-announcement-specs |access-date=2024-10-30 |website=The Verge |language=en}} The M4 series is built upon [[TSMC]]'s second-generation [[3 nanometer|3-nanometer]] process and contains 28 billion transistors.{{Cite web |last=Sohail |first=Omar |date=2024-05-07 |title=Apple’s M4 Is Made Using Second-Generation 3nm Process, Sports Higher Core Count, Upgraded Neural Engine; New GPU Supports Mesh Shading And Other Upgrades |url=https://wccftech.com/apple-m4-officially-announced/ |access-date=2024-07-11 |website=Wccftech |language=en-US}} == Design == The base M4 features a 10-[[CPU core|core]] design made up of four performance cores and six efficiency cores (with one performance core disabled on binned models). The SoC also includes a 10-core GPU (with [[Hardware acceleration|hardware-accelerated]] [[Ray tracing (graphics)|ray tracing]], dynamic caching, and mesh shading introduced with the M3), as well as a 16-core NPU. The M4 Neural Engine has been significantly improved compared to its predecessor, with the advertised capability to perform up to 38 trillion operations per second, claimed to be more than double the advertised performance of the M3. The M4 NPU performs over 60× faster than the A11 Bionic, and is approximately 3× faster than the original M1.{{Cite web |title=Introducing TSMC N3E As Seen In Apple M4 SoC {{!}} TechInsights |url=https://www.techinsights.com/blog/introducing-tsmc-n3e-seen-apple-m4-soc |access-date=2024-07-11 |website=www.techinsights.com}} The M4 is packaged with [[LPDDR|LPDDR5X]] unified memory, supporting 120GB/sec of memory [[Bandwidth (computing)|bandwidth]]. The SoC is currently offered in 8GB,{{Nbsp}}16GB, 24GB, and 32GB configurations. It is also Apple's first SoC to use the [[AArch64|ARMv9]] CPU architecture (specifically ARMv9.2-A).{{Cite web |last=Larabel |first=Michael |date=2024-06-15 |title=Apple M4 Support Added To The LLVM Compiler, Confirming Its ISA Capabilities |url=https://www.phoronix.com/news/Apple-M4-Added-To-LLVM-Clang |access-date=2024-06-16 |website=phoronix.com}} ===M4 Pro=== The M4 Pro features an up to 14-core CPU, with 10 performance cores and 4 efficiency cores, along with up to a 20-core GPU that Apple claims is twice as powerful as that in the M4 when used in the corresponding MacBook Pro. The M4 Pro is available with up to 64GB unified memory (Mac Mini) with a theoretical maximum bandwidth of 273GB/sec.{{cite press release|title=Apple introduces M4 Pro and M4 Max|url=https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2024/10/apple-introduces-m4-pro-and-m4-max|publisher=Apple Inc.|date=October 30, 2024}} ===M4 Max=== The M4 Max chip comes with up to 16 CPU cores, 40 GPU cores, and 16 Neural Engine cores, addressing up to 128GB unified memory with over half a terabyte per second (546GB/sec) of memory bandwidth.{{Cite press release |title= Apple’s new MacBook Pro features the incredibly powerful M4 family of chips |url=https://www.apple.com/eg/newsroom/2024/10/apples-new-macbook-pro-features-the-incredibly-powerful-m4-family-of-chips/ |publisher=Apple Inc. |language=en-US |location=Cupertino, CA |date=October 30, 2024 |access-date=November 10, 2024}} == Performance == Apple claims up to 50% more CPU performance and 4× more GPU performance on the M4 compared to the M2. The M4 competes for the highest-scoring consumer SoC for single-core benchmarks according to various sources such as the [[Geekbench]] [[benchmark (computing)|benchmarking]] suite{{Cite web |last=Norem |first=Josh |date=May 10, 2024 |title=The Apple M4 Is the New Geekbench Single-Core Performance Champion |url=https://www.extremetech.com/computing/the-apple-m4-is-the-new-geekbench-single-core-performance-champion |access-date=May 12, 2024 |website=ExtremeTech |publisher=[[Ziff Davis]]}} and [[Passmark Software|Passmark Software's CPU benchmarks]].{{Cite web |title=Apple M4 10 Core Benchmark |url=https://www.cpubenchmark.net/cpu.php?cpu=Apple+M4+10+Core&id=6040 |access-date=2024-10-20 |website=www.cpubenchmark.net}} Compared to other modern CPUs, the M4 does not outperform the M3 ''Pro'' in multi-core performance {{Cite web |date=October 27, 2024 |title=Geekbench |url=https://browser.geekbench.com/v6/cpu/8495624}} but it does in single-core performance{{Cite web |title=Mac15,9 - Geekbench |url=https://browser.geekbench.com/v6/cpu/3364975 |access-date=2024-10-20 |website=browser.geekbench.com}}{{Cite web |title=Apple M3 Max 16 Core Benchmark |url=https://www.cpubenchmark.net/cpu.php?cpu=Apple+M3+Max+16+Core&id=5748 |access-date=2024-10-20 |website=www.cpubenchmark.net}} and competes with [[AMD]]'s [[Ryzen]] 7 9700X{{Cite web |title=Gigabyte Technology Co., Ltd. X670E AORUS MASTER - Geekbench |url=https://browser.geekbench.com/v6/cpu/7231408 |access-date=2024-10-20 |website=browser.geekbench.com}}{{Cite web |title=AMD Ryzen 7 9700X Benchmark |url=https://www.cpubenchmark.net/cpu.php?cpu=AMD+Ryzen+7+9700X&id=6205 |access-date=2024-10-20 |website=www.cpubenchmark.net}} and [[Intel]]'s [[Intel Core|Core]] i9-14900K.{{Cite web |title=ASUS System Product Name - Geekbench |url=https://browser.geekbench.com/v6/cpu/3869916 |access-date=2024-10-20 |website=browser.geekbench.com}}{{Cite web |title=Intel Core i9-14900K Benchmark |url=https://www.cpubenchmark.net/cpu.php?cpu=Intel+Core+i9-14900K&id=5717 |access-date=2024-10-20 |website=www.cpubenchmark.net}}{{Cite web |title=iPad16,6 - Geekbench |url=https://browser.geekbench.com/v6/cpu/6016039 |access-date=2024-10-20 |website=browser.geekbench.com}}{{Cite web |title=Apple M4 10 Core Benchmark |url=https://www.cpubenchmark.net/cpu.php?cpu=Apple+M4+10+Core&id=6040 |access-date=2024-10-20 |website=www.cpubenchmark.net}} In [[Multithreading (computer architecture)|multithreaded]] performance, the M4 performs similarly to the 12-core M3 Pro.{{Cite web |last=Mayo |first=Benjamin |date=May 11, 2024 |title=iPad Pro with M4 chip boasts impressive performance jump compared to just-released M3 MacBook Air |url=https://9to5mac.com/2024/05/11/ipad-pro-with-m4-chip-geekbench-compared-m3/ |access-date=May 12, 2024 |website=[[9to5Mac]]}} == Additional features == The M4 is the first iPad SoC to support hardware-accelerated [[AV1]] decoding, as well as hardware-accelerated mesh shading and ray tracing introduced to MacBooks in the M3. A new [[display controller]] has also been implemented to support the [[iPad Pro (7th generation)]]'s Tandem [[OLED]] display.{{Cite web |date=2024-05-09 |title=M4 vs. M3: How much better are Apple's latest chips? |url=https://www.digitaltrends.com/computing/apple-m4-vs-m3/ |access-date=2024-07-11 |website=Digital Trends |language=en}} == Products that use the Apple M4 series == === M4 === * [[iPad Pro (7th generation)]]{{Cite press release |title=Apple unveils stunning new iPad Pro with the world's most advanced display, M4 chip, and Apple Pencil Pro |url=https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2024/05/apple-unveils-stunning-new-ipad-pro-with-m4-chip-and-apple-pencil-pro/ |publisher=Apple Inc. |language=en-US |location=Cupertino, CA |date=May 7, 2024 |access-date=May 8, 2024}} * [[IMac (Apple silicon)|iMac (2024)]] * [[Mac Mini|Mac Mini (2024)]]{{Cite web |title=Apple’s new Mac mini is more mighty, more mini, and built for Apple Intelligence |url=https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2024/10/apples-new-mac-mini-is-more-mighty-more-mini-and-built-for-apple-intelligence/ |access-date=2024-10-29 |website=Apple Newsroom |language=en-US}} * [[MacBook Pro (Apple silicon)|MacBook Pro (14-inch, 2024)]] === M4 Pro === * [[Mac Mini|Mac Mini (2024)]] * [[MacBook Pro (Apple silicon)|MacBook Pro (14-inch and 16-inch, 2024)]] === M4 Max === * [[MacBook Pro (Apple silicon)|MacBook Pro (14-inch and 16-inch, 2024)]] == Comparison with other SoCs == *The table below shows comparable SoCs {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" ! rowspan="2" |Variant ! colspan="2" |CPU ! colspan="3" |GPU ! colspan="2" |NPU ! colspan="3" |Memory ! rowspan="2" |Transistor
